Hence One who pretends to skill or knowledge of any kind which he does not possess; an ignorant and impudent pretender; a charlatan.

Synonyms Quack, Empiric, Mountebank, Charlatan. A quack is, by derivation, one who talks much without wisdom, and, specifically, talks of his own power to heal; hence, any ignorant pretender to medical knowledge or skill. Empiric is a more elevated term for one who goes by mere experience in the trial of remedies, and is without knowledge of the medical sciences or of the clinical observations and opinions of others; hence, an incompetent, self-confident practitioner. A mountebank is generally a quack , but may be a pretender in any line. Charlatan (literally ‘chatterer’) is primarily applied, not to a person belonging to any particular profession or occupation, but to a pretentious cheat of any sort.

a hand instrument used chiefly at sea to measure the altitude of the sun or other celestial body in ascertaining the vessel's position. It consists of a frame in the form of an octant having a graduated scale upon its arc, and an index arm, or alidade pivoted at its apex. Mirrors, called the index glass and the horizon glass, are fixed one upon the index arm and the other upon one side of the frame, respectively. When the instrument is held upright, the index arm may be swung so that the index glass will reflect an image of the sun upon the horizon glass, and when the reflected image of the sun coincides, to the observer's eye, with the horizon as seen directly through an opening at the side of the horizon glass, the index shows the sun's altitude upon the scale; -- more properly, but less commonly, called an octant .

an appendage of the artificial globe, consisting of a slip of brass of the length of a quadrant of one of the great circles of the globe, and graduated. It may be fitted to the meridian, and being movable round to all points of the horizon, serves as a scale in measuring altitudes, azimuths, etc.

quadrifid.explanation: Divided, or deeply cleft, into four parts
Divided, or deeply cleft, into four parts.

quadrifocal.explanation: Of or pertaining to lenses that have four different powers per eye .

quadrifoil.explanation: Four-leaved; having the leaves in whorls of four.

quadrifoliolate.explanation: botany , having four leaflets: said of a compound leaf.

quadrifolium.explanation: In geometry , the rose of four leaves. See rose , 18.

quadriform.explanation: Having four forms , parts or aspects

quadrifurcate.explanation: Furcate ( fork or divide ) into four branches or channels .

quadrifurcated.explanation: Having four forks or branches ; quadrifurcate .
Simple past tense and past participle of quadrifurcate .

quadriga.explanation: A two-wheeled chariot drawn by four horses abreast.
In classical antiquity , a two-wheeled chariot drawn by four horses, which were harnessed all abreast.
A car or chariot drawn by four horses abreast.
A Roman racing chariot drawn by four horses abreast .
A team of four horses , especially as used in chariot racing .

quadrigamist.explanation: One who has four wives or husbands at the same time.
someone who has four wives or four husbands at the same time

quadrigatus.explanation: A Roman silver denarius with the representation of a four-horse chariot.
A medium-sized silver coin minted by the Roman Republic during the 3rd century B.C. .

quadrigeminal.explanation: Fourfold; having four similar parts, or two pairs of similar parts.
two pairs of lobes, or elevations, on the dorsal side of the midbrain of most mammals; the optic lobes. The anterior pair are called the nates , and the posterior the testes .
Having four parts, or two pairs

quadrigeminate.explanation: botany , growing in fours, as the cells of certain algæ.

quadrigeminous.explanation: anatomy and zoology , specifically, pertaining to the optic lobes or corpora quadrigemina of any mammal, known in human anatomy as the nates and testes , which appear as two pairs of lobes or tubercles on the morphologically superior surface of the midbrain or mesencephalon, close to the pineal gland, behind the third ventricle, over the aqueduct of Sylvius. See corpus and quadrigemina.

quadrigenarious.explanation: Having or consisting of four hundred .

quadrijugate.explanation: botany , pinnate with four pairs of leaflets: as, a quadrijugate leaf.
Pinnate , with four pairs of leaflets .

quadrijugous.explanation: Pinnate, with four pairs of leaflets.

quadrilateral.explanation: A figure formed of four Straight lines.

Milit. , the space inclosed between, and defended by, four fortresses: as, the Bulgarian quadrilateral. The most famous quadrilateral was that in northern Italy, inclosed by the fortresses of Peschiera, Mantua, Verona, and Legnago.
Having four sides, and consequently four angles; quadrangular.
A plane figure having four sides, and consequently four angles; a quadrangular figure; any figure formed by four lines.
An area defended by four fortresses supporting each other.
the figure made up of the six straight lines that can be drawn through four points, A, B, C, I, the lines being supposed to be produced indefinitely.

quadriliteral.explanation: A word or a root consisting of four letters or containing four consonants.
Used to describe word roots in Semitic languages which consist of four letters
A word root in a Semitic language which consists of four letters

quadrille.explanation: A small squadron; a cluster of richly caparisoned horsemen at a tournament or mounted fête. They were distinguished by different colors.
A game played by four persons with forty cards, which are the remainder of the pack after the tens, nines, and eights are discarded.
A square dance for four couples, consisting regularly of five parts or movements, each complete in itself — namely, le pantalon, Pété, la poule, la trénise (or la pastourelle ), and la finale.
Any single set of dancers or maskers arranged in four sets or groups.
Any square dance resembling the quadrille.
Marked with squares, generally by thin lines crossing at right angles and at equal intervals.
A dance having five figures, in common time, four couples of dancers being in each set.
The appropriate music for a quadrille.
A game played by four persons with forty cards, being the remainder of an ordinary pack after the tens, nines, and eights are discarded.
A dance originating from the mid 1700s with four dancers forming a square, rather much like the modern square dance .
Quadrille ruled graph paper , quad paper .
a square dance of 5 or more figures for 4 or more couples

quadrillion.explanation: The fourth power of a million according to the system of numeration called English; but the fifth power of a thousand according to the French system, commonly used in the United States.

According to the French notation, which is followed also upon the Continent and in the United States, a unit with fifteen ciphers annexed; according to the English notation, the number produced by involving a million to the fourth power, or the number represented by a unit with twenty-four ciphers annexed. See the Note under numeration .
A thousand trillion : 1 followed by fifteen zeros, 1015.
A million trillion : 1 followed by twenty-four zeros, 1024.
Any very large number, exceeding normal description.
the number that is represented as a one followed by 15 zeros
the number that is represented as a one followed by 24 zeros

quadrillionth.explanation: The ordinal number matching the number quadrillion in a series.
One of a quadrillion equal parts.
One of a quadrillion parts; the quotient of unity divided by a quadrillion.
The ordinal form of the number one quadrillion .
The person or thing in the quadrillionth position.
One of a quadrillion equal parts of a whole
one part in a quadrillion equal parts
the ordinal number of one quadrillion in counting order

quadrilobate.explanation: botany and zoology , having four lobes or lobules.

quadrilocular.explanation: botany , having four cells or compartments; four-celled: as, a quadrilocular pericarp.
anatomy and zoology , having four cavities or compartments: chiefly an epithet of the heart of mammale and birds.

quadrine.explanation: A small, copper coin ; a farthing

quadrinomial.explanation: In algebra , an expression consisting of four terms.
A polynomial of four terms connected by the signs plus or minus.
Consisting of four names or parts or terms.
An expression consisting of four terms.

quadrinucleate.explanation: botany , having four nuclei, as the spores of some fungi.

quadriparous.explanation: ornithology , laying four eggs, and only four; being of the Quadriparæ : as, quadriparous birds.
Having given birth to four offspring .

quadripartite.explanation: Consisting of or divided into four parts.
law , having four parts, or parties: as, a quadripartite government; a quadripartite agreement, etc.

botany and zoology , parted into four; divided to the base or entirely into four parts; in architecture , divided, as a vault, by the system of construction employed, into four compartments. Such a vault is the cardinal type of medieval Pointed vaulting.
A book or treatise divided into four parts or treatises; a tetrabiblion: as, the last two books of Ptolemy's Quadripartite; the quadripartite (four Gospels) of the New Testament.
Involving four parties or participants ; four-party.

quadripartitely.explanation: In a quadripartite fashion; into four parts.

quadripartition.explanation: A division by four or into four parts.
A division or distribution by four, or into four parts; also, a taking the fourth part of any quantity or number.

quadripennate.explanation: entomology , having four wings — that is, four functional wings, an anterior pair being not converted into elytra or wing-cases.
Having four wings; -- said of insects.

quadripinnate.explanation: botany , having four pinnæ or side leaflets.

quadriplegia.explanation: Complete paralysis of the body from the neck down.
paralysis of both arms and both legs

quadriplegic.explanation: Of, related to, or suffering from quadriplegia .
a person who is paralyzed in both arms and both legs

quadripolar.explanation: biology , having four poles: said of a cell.

quadriporticus.explanation: a nearly square courtyard surrounded by colonnaded porticoes

quadripulmonary.explanation: Arachnida , having two pairs of pulmonary sacs; tetrapneumonous: opposed to bipulmonary.

quadriquadric.explanation: A skew quartic curve, the intersection of two quadric surfaces. There are other quartics not of this description.
geometry , determined by the intersection of two quadric surfaces.

quadriradiate.explanation: botany , having four radii or prolongations: as, a quadriradiate mass of chlorophyl.
A sponge-spicule which has four rays.

quadrireme.explanation: A galley with four banks of oars or rowers, mentioned as in use occasionally among the ancient Greeks and Romans.
A galley with four banks of oars or rowers.
a galley with four banks of oars

quadrisected.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of quadrisect .

quadrisection.explanation: A section into four equal parts.
The action of dividing something into four parts.

quadriserial.explanation: botany , having the four regular series or whorls in the flower, that is, calyx, corolla, stamens, and pistils.

quadrisetose.explanation: entomology , bearing four setæ or bristles.

quadrisulcate.explanation: mammalogy , having a four-parted hoof; four-toed; quadridigitate.

quadrisyllable.explanation: A word consisting of four syllables.
A word consisting of four syllables.

quadriurate.explanation: A salt of uric acid of which the constitution may be represented by the general formula MH(C 5 H 2 N 4 O 3 ).H 2 (C 5 H 2 -N 4 O 3 ),M standing for a monad metal, such as potassium or sodium.

quadrivalence.explanation: The quality or state of being quadrivalent; tetravalence.

quadrivalent.explanation: chem. , noting an atom the equivalence of which is four, or an element one atom of which is equivalent, in combining power, to four atoms of hydrogen; tetradic; tetratomic.
Having a valence of four; capable of combining with, being replaced by, or compared with, four monad atoms; tetravalent; -- said of certain atoms and radicals.

quadrivalve.explanation: One of a set of four folds or leaves forming a door.
A door, shutter, or the like, having four folds.
Dehiscent into four similar parts; four-valved.
A door , shutter , etc. with four folds .

quadrivalvular.explanation: zoology and botany , having four valves or valvular parts.
Having or pertaining to four valves .

quadrivial.explanation: quadrivial astrology is astrology in the sense in which astrology is a branch of the quadrivium — that is, astronomy.
One of the four arts constituting the quadrivium.
One of the four “liberal arts” making up the quadrivium.
Having four ways meeting in a point.
Any of the four "liberal arts" making up the quadrivium .

quadrivium.explanation: The higher division of the seven liberal arts in the Middle Ages, composed of geometry, astronomy, arithmetic, and music.
A place where four ways meet.

The collective name of the four branches of mathematics according to the Pythagoreans—arithmetic (treating of number in itself), music (treating of applied number), geometry (treating of stationary number), and astronomy (treating of number in motion).
The four “liberal arts,” arithmetic, music, geometry, and astronomy; -- so called by the schoolmen. See trivium .
The higher division of the seven liberal arts in the Middle Ages , composed of geometry , astronomy , arithmetic , and music .
(Middle Ages) a higher division of the curriculum in a medieval university involving arithmetic and music and geometry and astronomy

quadrivoltine.explanation: A silkworm which yields four crops of cocoons a year.
Having four broods or litters in one year.

quadroon.explanation: A person having white ancestors except for one black grandparent. Used especially as a classification under certain European colonial legal systems and now considered offensive.
The offspring of a mulatto and a white person; a person having one fourth African blood.
The offspring of a mulatto and a white person; a person quarter-blooded.
A person of three-fourths Caucasian descent and one fourth African descent.
Having three-fourths Caucasian descent and one-fourth African descent.
an offspring of a mulatto and a white parent; a person who is one-quarter black

quadrumana.explanation: Mammalia named by Blumenbach in 1791, including all kinds of apes, monkeys, and lemurs; the quadrumanous mammals: so called because their hind as well as fore feet can be used as hands.

A division of the Primates comprising the apes and monkeys; -- so called because the hind foot is usually prehensile, and the great toe opposable somewhat like a thumb. Formerly the Quadrumana were considered an order distinct from the Bimana, which last included man alone.

quadrumane.explanation: An animal having four hands and feet with opposable digits, specifically a member of the now obsolete order of mammals Quadrumana , comprising all non-human primates ; a primate .
Pertaining to such an animal; quadrumanous ; loosely, "ape-like".

quadrumanous.explanation: Having opposable first digits on both the feet and the hands, used for gripping and climbing. Many primates are quadrumanous.
Having four hands; of or pertaining to the Quadrumana.
Having four feet whose first digits are opposable ; applies to all non-human primates .

quadrumvir.explanation: One of four commissioners appointed for some special object.

quadrumvirate.explanation: A group of four people joined in authority or office, especially a government of four people.
A group of four men, especially four men joined in authority

quadruped.explanation: aliped and biped : correlated with quadrumanous and pedimanous : chiefly said of mammals, but also of four-footed reptiles, as lizards and tortoises. Compare quadrumanous .
A four-footed or quadruped animal: especially, a four-footed mammal, as distinguished from a biped , as man or a bird.
An animal having four feet, as most mammals and reptiles; -- often restricted to the mammals.
a mammal ambulating on all fours
an animal especially a mammal having four limbs specialized for walking

quadrupedal.explanation: Having four feet; of or pertaining to a quadruped.

quadrupedism.explanation: The state of being a quadruped; the condition of being four-footed, as a beast.

quadruplane.explanation: A plane quadrilateral having its opposite or alternate sides equal and one pair of these crossing each other.

A system of four plane links pivoted together so that the pivots are vertexes of a contraparallelogram. It is an extension by Sylvester and Kempe of what Sylvester called the plagiograph or skew-pantograph to Hart's contraparallelogram.
An airplane with four superposed main supporting surfaces. Contrasted with triplane biplane and monoplane . They are now used only for hobbyist or historical activities.

quadruplator.explanation: In Roman law , an informer who was entitled to a fourth part of confiscated property upon conviction and confiscation following an information given by him.

quadruple.explanation: Consisting of four parts or members.
Four times as much in size, strength, number, or amount.
Having four beats to the measure.
To multiply or be multiplied by four.
A number, sum, etc., four times as great as that taken as the standard: as, to receive the quadruple of a given sum.
four times the sum or number; a fourfold amount.
that in which each measure is divided into four equal parts.
To be multiplied by four; to increase fourfold; to become four times as much.
To multiply by four; to increase fourfold; to double; to double twice.
Being four times as long, as big or as many of something.
To multiply something by four times.
a quantity that is four times as great as another
a set of four similar things considered as a unit
four times as great or many

quadrupled.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of quadruple .

quadrupleness.explanation: The state of being quadruple or quadrupled.

quadruples.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of quadruple .

quadruplet.explanation: One of four offspring born in a single birth.
A group or combination of four associated by common properties or behavior.
A group of four notes having the time value of three notes of the same kind.

Any combination of four objects or parts grouped, united, or acting together: as, a quadruplet of springs, consisting of four elliptic springs coupled together and acting as one spring. Also called quartet .
One of four born at a single birth.
A collection or combination of four of a kind.
Four children born in the same labor.
A cycle for carrying four riders, so arranged that all the riders can assist in the propulsion.
One of a group of four babies born from the same mother during the same birth.
one of four children born at the same time from the same pregnancy
a set of four similar things considered as a unit
the cardinal number that is the sum of three and one

quadruplex.explanation: An instrument by means of which four messages may be transmitted simultaneously over one wire.
a system by which four messages, two in each direction, may be sent simultaneously over the wire.
of or relating to a system in telegraphy by which four messages can be sent on one wire simultaneously .

quadruplicate.explanation: Fourth in a group of four identical things.
One of a group of four identical things.
To multiply or be multiplied four times.
quadruplicate ratio or proportion. Also quadriplicated .
One of four things corresponding in all respects to one another, or to a common original.
To make fourfold; to double twice; to quadruple.
Fourfold; doubled twice; four times repeated.
in quadruplicate: four times over, in four copies
any four copies; any of four things that correspond to one another exactly

quadruplicated.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of quadruplicate .

quadruplicates.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of quadruplicate .

quadruplication.explanation: The act of making fourfold; a taking of four times the simple sum or amount.
The act of making fourfold; a taking four times the simple sum or amount.

quadrupling.explanation: increase by a factor of four

quadruply.explanation: To a fourfold quantity; so as to be, or cause to be, quadruple.

quadrupole.explanation: a distribution of either electric charge or magnetization equivalent to two dipoles that point in opposite directions
a magnet with two north poles and two south poles , used to focus a beam of particles

quaere.explanation: To ask or query ; used imperatively to introduce a question or signify doubt.

quaestio.explanation: (in ancient Rome) A commission to inquire into a criminal matter given to a citizen (the quaesitor ) who then reported to whoever appointed him.

quaestor.explanation: Any of various public officials in ancient Rome responsible for finance and administration in various areas of government and the military.
an ancient Roman official responsible for public revenue and other financial affairs.

quaestorship.explanation: The office or status of quaestor .

quaff.explanation: The act of quaffing; also, the quantity of liquor drunk at once; a draught.
To drink with relish; to drink copiously of; to swallow in large draughts.
To drink or imbibe , especially with vigour .
The act of quaffing, a deep draught .
to swallow hurriedly or greedily or in one draught

quaffed.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of quaff .

quaffer.explanation: One who quaffs or drinks much.
One who quaffs, or drinks largely.

quaffs.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of quaff .

quag.explanation: A shaking, marshy soil; a quagmire.
a soft wet area of low-lying land that sinks underfoot

quagga.explanation: An equid (Equus quagga subsp. quagga) of southern Africa, extinct since the late 1800s. It was brownish with stripes only on the head, neck, and front of the body.

An African solidungulate quadruped of the horse family, Equus or Hippotigris quagga , related to the ass and zebra, but not fully striped like the latter, not being banded on the hind quarters and legs.
Burchell's zebra, Equus or Hippotigris burchelli , closely related to the above, but striped throughout like the zebra: more fully called bonte-quagga . See cut under dauw .

A South African wild ass ( Equus quagga syn. Hippotigris quagga ). The upper parts are reddish brown, becoming paler behind and behind and beneath, with dark stripes on the face, neck, and fore part of the body. The species became extinct in the late 1800's, largely due to excessive hunting.

A southern African subspecies of zebra , Equus quagga quagga, extinct since 1883. The upper parts are reddish brown, becoming paler behind and beneath, with dark stripes on the face, neck, and fore part of the body. Taxonomic name: Equus quagga .
mammal of South Africa that resembled a zebra; extinct since late 19th century

quaggier.explanation: comparative form of quaggy : more quaggy

quaggiest.explanation: superlative form of quaggy : most quaggy .

quaggy.explanation: Of the nature of a quagmire; yielding or trembling under the foot, as soft, wet earth; spongy; boggy.
Soft or flabby (of a person etc.).

quagmire.explanation: Land with a soft muddy surface.
A difficult or precarious situation; a predicament.
Soft, wet, boggy land that trembles under the foot; a marsh; a bog; a fen.
Synonyms Slough, Bog , etc. See marsh .
Soft, wet, miry land, which shakes or yields under the feet.
A swampy , soggy area of ground .
A perilous , mixed up and troubled situation; a hopeless tangle ; a predicament .
a soft wet area of low-lying land that sinks underfoot

quahaug.explanation: An edible clam with a hard shell found along the Atlantic Coast of North America . (scientific name Venus mercenaria )
Large clams used in chowders and other clam dishes.
Atlantic coast round clams with hard shells; large clams usually used for chowders or other clam dishes
an edible American clam; the heavy shells were used as money by some American Indians

quahog.explanation: An edible clam (Mercenaria mercenaria) of the Atlantic coast of North America, having a hard rounded shell.
The large edible round clam of the Atlantic coast of the United States, Venus mercenaria , much used for soups and chowders. See clam , and cut under dimyarian .
An American market clam ( Venus mercenaria ). It is sold in large quantities, and is highly valued as food. Called also round clam , and hard clam .
An edible clam with a hard shell found along the Atlantic Coast of North America; scientific name Venus mercenaria .
Very small clams used in chowders and other clam dishes.
Atlantic coast round clams with hard shells; large clams usually used for chowders or other clam dishes
an edible American clam; the heavy shells were used as money by some American Indians

quaich.explanation: A trophy resembling such a cup.
A traditional, shallow, two-handled Scottish cup symbolising friendship. It was originally used to toast the arrival or departure of a visitor.

quaigh.explanation: A shallow drinking-cup, made of small staves hooped together: it is usually of wood, but sometimes of silver.
A small shallow cup or drinking vessel.
a traditional, shallow, two-handled Scottish cup symbolising friendship

quail.explanation: To shrink back in fear; cower.
Any of various primarily ground-dwelling birds of the genus Coturnix, especially C. coturnix, small in size and having mottled brown plumage and a short tail.
Any of various similar or related birds of the Americas, such as the bobwhite or the California quail.
The mountain quail, Oreortyx pictus , of the western United States: so named from its bright marking of white and chestnut.
An Australian hemipod, or button-quail, Turnix varius.
A small gallinaceous bird of the Old World, related to the partridge, and belonging to the genus Coturnix.

One of the various small gallinaceous birds more or less closely resembling the quail proper: loosely applied, with or without a qualifying term, especially in the United States, to all the species of Ortyx or Colinus, Lophortyx, Oreortyx, Callipepla, Cyrtonyx , and other genera of American Ortyginæ or Odontophorinæ.
A prostitute. Also called plover .
To curdle; to coagulate, as milk.
To cause to fail in spirit or power; to quell; to crush; to subdue.
To die; to perish; hence, to wither; to fade.
To become quelled; to become cast down; to sink under trial or apprehension of danger; to lose the spirit and power of resistance; to lose heart; to give way; to shrink; to cower.

Any gallinaceous bird belonging to Coturnix and several allied genera of the Old World, especially the common European quail ( Coturnix communis ), the rain quail ( Coturnix Coromandelica ) of India, the stubble quail ( Coturnix pectoralis ), and the Australian swamp quail ( Synoicus australis ).

Any one of several American partridges belonging to Colinus, Callipepla, and allied genera, especially the bobwhite (called Virginia quail , and Maryland quail ), and the California quail ( Calipepla Californica ).
Any one of numerous species of Turnix and allied genera, native of the Old World, as the Australian painted quail ( Turnix varius ). See Turnix .
A prostitute; -- so called because the quail was thought to be a very amorous bird.
a small Asiatic quail-like bird of the genus Turnix, as Turnix taigoor , a black-breasted species, and the hill bustard quail ( Turnix ocellatus ). See Turnix .
one of several small Asiatic species of Turnix, as Turnix Sykesii , which is said to be the smallest game bird of India.
See under Mountain .
a call or pipe for alluring quails into a net or within range.
any one of several American ground pigeons belonging to Geotrygon and allied genera.
the New Zealand sparrow hawk ( Hieracidea Novæ-Hollandiæ ).
See Quail call, above.
the dowitcher, or red-breasted snipe; -- called also robin snipe , and brown snipe .
the turnstone.
Any of various small game birds of the genera Coturnix , Anurophasis or Perdicula in the Old World family Phasianidae or of the New World family Odontophoridae .
flesh of quail; suitable for roasting or broiling if young; otherwise must be braised
small gallinaceous game birds
draw back, as with fear or pain

quailed.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of quail .

quailery.explanation: A place where quails are bred and fattened.

quails.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of quail .

quaily.explanation: The upland plover, or Bartram's sandpiper, Tringa bartramia or Bartramia longicauda. See cut under Bartramia .
The upland plover; a large American sandpiper , Bartramia longicauda, a game bird.

quaint.explanation: Charmingly odd, especially in an old-fashioned way.
Unfamiliar or unusual in character; strange.
Prudent; wise; hence, crafty; artful; wily.
Characterized by ingenuity or art; finely fashioned; skillfully wrought; elegant; graceful; nice; neat.
Curious and fanciful; affected; odd; whimsical; antique; archaic; singular; unusual
very strange or unusual; odd or even incongruous in character or appearance
strange in an interesting or pleasing way

quainter.explanation: comparative form of quaint : more quaint

quaintest.explanation: superlative form of quaint : most quaint .

quaintly.explanation: In a quaint manner; oddly ; strangely .
in a strange but not unpleasant manner

quaintness.explanation: Fancifulness; oddity; whimsicality; queerness; especially, odd, old-fashioned appearance or manner.
The state or fact of being quaint ; having old-fashioned charm.
the quality of being quaint and old-fashioned
strangeness as a consequence of being old fashioned

quake.explanation: To shake or tremble, as from instability or shock.
To shiver or shudder, as with cold or from strong emotion. synonym : shake .
A shake; a trembling; a tremulous agitation; a shuddering.
A rather large basket with rounded bottom, made of open wickerwork, used for packing, storing provisions, etc.
To be agitated with quick, short motions continually repeated; to shake with fear, cold, etc.; to shudder; to tremble.
To shake, vibrate, or quiver, either from not being solid, as soft, wet land, or from violent convulsion of any kind
A tremulous agitation; a quick vibratory movement; a shudder; a quivering.
An earthquake , a trembling of the ground with force.
To tremble or shake with fear.
shaking and vibration at the surface of the earth resulting from underground movement along a fault plane of from volcanic activity

quaked.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of quake .

quakeproof.explanation: Designed or constructed to withstand or resist the effects of an earthquake.

quakerdom.explanation: Quakers as a class; the world of Quakers, with their tenets, aims, manners, customs, etc.

quakeress.explanation: A woman who is a member of the Society of Friends.

quakerish.explanation: Like or pertaining to a Quaker; Quakerlike.

quakers.explanation: a Christian sect founded by George Fox about 1660; commonly called Quakers

quaketail.explanation: The yellow wagtail; any bird of the genus Budytes , as B. flava.

quakier.explanation: comparative form of quaky : more quaky

quakiest.explanation: superlative form of quaky : most quaky .

quaking.explanation: Populus tremuloides ), the leaves of which tremble in the lightest breeze. It much resembles the European aspen. See Aspen .
The action of the verb to quake .

quakingly.explanation: In a quaking fashion, especially with fear .

qual.explanation: An examination or contest that qualifies one to advance to the next level of accomplishment or competition.
Qualifying exam. An exam taken by someone (usually a grad student or prospective grad student ) to measure their mastery in something, usually an academic field.

quale.explanation: A property, such as whiteness, considered independently from things having the property.
A Middle English dialectal form of whale .
An object named or considered as having a quality.

Specifically In psychology , in the phrases spatial quale, quote of spatiality , the irreducible element or attribute of spaciousness, bidimensional, tridimensional, or indefinite, posited by nativistic theories of space-perception for some or all sensations.
A nativistic theory of space perception. See quale , 2.
A property considered separately from a thing having that property.

qualifiable.explanation: Capable of being qualified; abatable; modifiable.

qualification.explanation: The act of qualifying or the condition of being qualified.
A quality, ability, or accomplishment that makes a person suitable for a particular position or task.
A condition or circumstance that must be met or complied with.
A restriction or modification.
The act of qualifying, or the state of being qualified, by change or modification; specifically, adaptation; fitness.
A quality adapting a person or thing to particular circumstances, uses, or ends.

Synonyms and Quality, Property, Attribute, Accident, Characteristic, Character, Affection, Predicate, Mark, Difference, Diathesis, Determination. Quality is that which makes or helps to make a person or thing such as he or it is. It is not universal, and in one popular sense it implies an excellence or a defect. In popular speech a quality is intellectual or moral; in metaphysics it may be also physical. A property is that which is viewed as peculiarly one's own, a peculiar quality. An attribute is a high and lofty character: the attributes of Cod are natural, as omniscience, omnipotence, etc., and moral, as holiness, justice, mercy, etc. “ Accident is an abbreviated expression for accidental or contingent quality.” ( Sir W. Hamilton , Metaph., vi.) Characteristic is not a term of logic or philosophy; it stands for a personal, peculiar, or distinguishing quality: as, yellow in skin, horn, milk, etc., is a characteristic of Guernsey cattle. Characteristics may be mental, moral, or physical. Character is the most general of these words; a character is anything which is true of a subject. In another sense character (as a collective term) is the sum of the characteristics of a person or thing, especially the moral characteristics. The word always views them as making a unit or whole, and has lower and higher uses. The other words are somewhat technical. Affection is used in various senses. Predicate and mark are very general words in logic. Difference is a character distinguishing one class of objects from others. Diathesis , the corresponding Greek form, is applied in medicine to peculiarities of constitution. Determination is a more recent philosophical term denoting a character in general.

Synonyms and Quarrel, Altercation, Affray, Fray, Mêlée, Brawl, Broil, Scuffle, Wrangle, Squabble, Feud. A quarrel is a matter of ill feeling and hard words in view of supposed wrong: it stops just short of blows; any use beyond this is now figurative. Altercation is the spoken part of a quarrel, the parties speaking alternately. An altercation is thus a quarrelsome dispute between two persons or two sides. Affray and fray express a quarrel that has come to blows in a public place: they are often used of the struggles of war, implying personal activity. Mêlée emphasizes the confusion in which those engaged in an affray or struggle are mingled. Brawl emphasizes the unbecoming character and noisiness of the quarrel; while broil adds the idea of entanglement, perhaps with several: two are enough for a brawl ; at least three are needed for a broil : as, a brawl with a neighbor; a neighborhood broil. A scuffle is, in this connection, a confused or undignified struggle, at close quarters, between two, to throw each other down, or a similar struggle of many. A wrangle is a severe, unreasoning, and noisy, perhaps confused, altercation. A squabble is a petty wrangle, but is even less dignified or irrational. A feud is a deeply rooted animosity between two sets of kindred, two parties, or possibly two persons. See animosity .

quickness.explanation: The state of being quick or alive; vital power or principle.
Speed; velocity; celerity; rapidity: as, the quickness of motion.
Activity; briskness; promptness; readiness: as, the quickness of the imagination or wit.

Synonyms Quickness, Fastness, Speed, Celerity, Swiftness, Fleetness, Rapidity, Velocity , haste, expedition, despatch, alertness, liveliness. Quickness is the generic term. Quickness, fastness, speed , and rapidity may have relation to time only, or to space passed through or over; the others apply only to space. “ Swift to hear,” in Jas. i. 19, is a bold figure. Celerity is swift voluntary movement; but we do not ordinarily speak of the movements of an animal as having celerity. Fleetness also is voluntary, and is applied to animals; we may speak by figure of the fleetness of a yacht. The word suggests quickness in getting over the ground by the use of the feet: we speak of the swiftness or rapidity of the swallow's or the pigeon's flight; the fleetness of Atalanta, a hound, a deer. Swiftness is presumably not too great for carefulness or thoroughness; rapidity may be too great for either. Velocity is the attribute of matter in motion; the word is especially a technical term for the rate of movement of matter, whether fast or slow. We speak also of the velocity of sound or light. Rapidity has less suggestion of personality than any of the others, except velocity. See nimble .

A person eager to learn news and scandal
a person who meddles in the affairs of others

quiesce.explanation: philology , to become silent, as a letter; come to have no sound.
To be silent, as a letter; to have no sound.
To make temporarily inactive or disabled .

quiesced.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of quiesce .

quiescence.explanation: The state or quality of being quiescent or inactive; rest; repose; inactivity; the state of a thing without motion or agitation: as, the quiescence of a volcano.
In philology , silence; the condition of not being heard in pronunciation: as, the quiescence of a letter.

In biology , quietude or inactivity; a state of animal life approaching torpidity, but in which the animal is capable of some motion, and may receive food: it is observed among insects during either hibernation or pupation, and in many other animals both higher and lower in the scale than these.
The state or quality of being quiescent.
The state of being quiescent ; dormancy .
Being at rest, quiet, still, inactive or motionless.
The action of bringing something to rest or making it quiescent; the action of coming to rest or to a quiescent state.
When a cell is in a term of no growth and no division.
a state of quiet (but possibly temporary) inaction

quiescency.explanation: Quiescence : the state of being quiescent , or at rest
a state of quiet (but possibly temporary) inaction

quiescent.explanation: Quiet, still, or inactive. synonym : inactive .
Characterized by an absence of upheaval or discord.
Having little or no sunspot activity.
philology , silent; not sounded; having no sound: as, a quiescent letter.
biology , physiologically inactive or motionless; resting, as an insect in the chrysalis state, or an encysted amœba.
Being in a state of repose; at rest; still; not moving.
Not ruffed with passion; unagitated; not in action; not excited; quiet; dormant; resting.
being quiet or still or inactive
marked by a state of tranquil repose

quiet.explanation: Making or characterized by little or no noise.
Free of turmoil and agitation; calm.
Providing or allowing relaxation; restful; soothing.
Not showy or bright; subdued.
Restrained, as in style; understated.
Out of public scrutiny; known or discussed by few.
The quality or condition of being quiet.
To cause to become quiet.
To make (a title) secure by freeing from uncertainties or adverse claims as to the ownership.
To become quiet.
Rest; repose; stillness.
An undisturbed condition; tranquillity; peace; repose.
An undisturbed state of mind; peace of soul; patience; calmness.
Synonyms Repose, Tranquillity , etc. See rest .
quiet the soul when it is agitated; to quiet the clamors of a nation; to quiet the disorders of a city.
To compose, soothe, sober; to still, silence, hush.
quieted.
quiet ; the sea was quiet.
quiet neighborhood.
quiet colors; a quiet dress.
Placid, Serene , etc. (see calm ), peaceful, unruffled, undisturbed.
To become still, silent, or calm; -- often with down .
The quality or state of being quiet, or in repose; as an hour or a time of quiet .
Freedom from disturbance, noise, or alarm; stillness; tranquillity; peace; security.
still; peaceful.
quietly.
disturbed; restless.
To stop motion in; to still; to reduce to a state of rest, or of silence.
To calm; to appease; to pacify; to lull; to allay; to tranquillize
In a state of rest or calm; without stir, motion, or agitation; still
Free from noise or disturbance; hushed; still.
Not excited or anxious; calm; peaceful; placid; settled
Not giving offense; not exciting disorder or trouble; not turbulent; gentle; mild; meek; contented.
Not showy; not such as to attract attention; undemonstrative
With little or no sound; denoting absence of disturbing noise .
Having little motion or activity ; calm .
Not busy , of low quantity .
Not talking much or not talking loudly ; reserved .
To become quiet, silent , still , tranquil , calm .
To cause someone to become quiet.
The absence of sound ; quietness .
the absence of movement ; stillness , tranquility
the absence of sound

quieted.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of quiet .

quieten.explanation: cause to be quiet or not talk

quietened.explanation: Simple past tense and past participle of quieten .

quietener.explanation: One who, or that which, quietens .

quietens.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of quieten .

quieter.explanation: One who or that which quiets.
One who, or that which, quiets.
comparative form of quiet : more quiet

quietest.explanation: superlative form of quiet : most quiet .

quietism.explanation: A form of Christian mysticism enjoining passive contemplation and the beatific annihilation of the will.
A state of quietness and passivity.

That form of mysticism which consists in the entire abnegation of all active exercise of the will and a purely passive meditation on God and divine things as the highest spiritual exercise and the means of bringing the soul into immediate union with the Godhead. Conspicuous exponents of quietism were Molinos and Mme. Guyon, in the seventeenth century. See Molinist .
The state or quality of being quiet; quietness.
Peace or tranquillity of mind; calmness; indifference; apathy; dispassion; indisturbance; inaction.

The system of the Quietists, who maintained that religion consists in the withdrawal of the mind from worldly interests and anxieties and its constant employment in the passive contemplation of God and his attributes.
A form of mysticism involving quiet contemplation .
a form of religious mysticism requiring withdrawal from all human effort and passive contemplation of God

quietist.explanation: One who believes in or practises quietism: applied especially [ capitalized ] to a body of mystics (followers of Molinos, a Spanish priest) in the latter part of the seventeenth century.
One who seeks or enjoys quietness; one who advocates a policy of quietness or inactivity.
One of a sect of mystics originated in the seventeenth century by Molinos, a Spanish priest living in Rome. See quietism .
Someone who is not socially or politically active .
a religious mystic who follows quietism

quietistic.explanation: Of or pertaining to the Quietists, or to Quietism.
Of or relating to quietism , a philosophy of passivity and non-involvement.

quietive.explanation: That which has the property of inducing quiet or calm, as a sedative medicine.

quietly.explanation: In a quiet state or manner; without motion; in a state of rest.
Without tumult, alarm, dispute, or disturbance; peaceably
Calmly, without agitation or violent emotion; patiently.
Noiselessly; silently; without remark or violent movement; in a manner to attract little or no observation.
with little or no activity or no agitation (`quiet' is a nonstandard variant for `quietly')

quietness.explanation: The state of being quiet, still, or free from action or motion; freedom from agitation, disturbance, or excitement; tranquillity; stillness; calmness.
The quality or state of being quiet; freedom from noise, agitation, disturbance, or excitement; stillness; tranquillity; calmness.
Absence of sound ; silence or hush .
Absence of disturbance ; calm , stillness or serenity .
the property of making no sound
a state of peace and quiet

quiets.explanation: Third-person singular simple present indicative form of quiet .

quietude.explanation: a state of peace and quiet

quietus.explanation: Something that serves to suppress, check, or eliminate.
A final discharge, as of a duty or debt.
A final discharge of an account; a final settlement; a quittance.
Hence A finishing or ending in general; stoppage.
Final discharge or acquittance, as from debt or obligation; that which silences claims; (Fig.) rest; death.
A stillness or pause; something that quiets or represses; removal from activity; especially: death.
euphemisms for death (based on an analogy between lying in a bed and in a tomb)

quiff.explanation: A tuft of hair, especially a forelock.
A puff or whiff , especially of tobacco smoke.
a prominent forelock (especially one brushed upward from the forehead)

quiina.explanation: A genus of polypetalous plants of the order Guttiferæ , type of the tribe Quiincæ.

quilisma.explanation: In medieval musical notation , a sign or neume denoting a shake or trill.

quill.explanation: The hollow stemlike main shaft of a feather.
Any of the larger wing or tail feathers of a bird.
A writing pen made from the shaft of a feather.
A plectrum for a stringed instrument of the clavichord type.
A pipe having a hollow stem.
A toothpick made from the stem of a feather.
One of the sharp hollow spines of a porcupine or hedgehog.
A spindle or bobbin around which yarn is wound in weaving.
A hollow shaft that rotates on a solid shaft when gears are engaged.
To wind (thread or yarn) onto a quill.
To make or press small ridges in (fabric).
To practice the art or craft of quilling.
A fold of a plaited or fluted ruff or ruffle.
In machinery , a hollow shaft: a cylinder; a pipe; specifically, in a turbine, the hollow shaft which carries the revolving blades or blade-wheels.
The stalk of a cane or reed.
A cane or reed pipe, such as those used in Pan's pipes.
One of the large, strong feathers of geese, swans, turkeys, crows, etc., used for writing-pens and the like.
A quill pen; hence, by extension, any pen, especially considered as the characteristic instrument of a writer.

One of the comparatively large flight-feathers or remiges of any bird, without reference to the use of such feathers for making quill pens; a quill-feather: as, the quills and coverts of the wing; sometimes extended to include the similar feathers of the tail.
The hard, hollow, horny part of the scape of any feather, which does not bear barbs, and by which the feather is inserted in the skin; the calamus, as distinguished from the rachis.
One of the much enlarged and peculiarly modified hairs with which some animals, as porcupines, are provided; a large hollow spine.
A piece of small reed or other light slender tube, used by weavers to wind thread upon, and by manufacturers to hold the wound silk and other thread prepared for sale.
A plectrum of quill, as of a goose, for playing on musical instruments of the lute and zither families.

In the harpsichord, spinet, and virginal, a small piece of quill projecting from the jack of each key (digital), and so set that when the key was depressed the corresponding string was twitched or twanged by it. Various other materials were used instead of quills.
In seal-engraving , the hollow shaft or mandril of the seal-engravers' lathe, in which the cutting-tools are secured to be revolved while the stones are held against them.
In mining , a train for igniting a blast, consisting of a quill filled with slow-burning powder: it is now superseded by the safety-fuse.
The faucet of a barrel.
In pharmacy , bark in a roll, such as is often formed in drying, as of cinnamon or cinchona.
To plaint in small cylindrical ridges, called quillings.
To wind on a quill, as thread or yarn.
One of the large feathers of a bird's wing, or one of the rectrices of the tail; also, the stock of such a feather.
A pen for writing made by sharpening and splitting the point or nib of the stock of a feather.
A spine of the hedgehog or porcupine.
The pen of a squid. See Pen .
The plectrum with which musicians strike the strings of certain instruments.
The tube of a musical instrument.
Something having the form of a quill.
The fold or plain of a ruff.
A spindle, or spool, as of reed or wood, upon which the thread for the woof is wound in a shuttle.
A hollow spindle.
A roll of dried bark.
a bit for boring resembling the half of a reed split lengthways and having its end sharpened like a gouge.

quillai.explanation: A middle-sized Chilian tree, Quillaia Saponaria.

quillaia.explanation: A genus of rosaceous trees, type of the tribe Quillaieæ.
An extract from the bark of the soapbark tree , Quillaja saponaria, used as a food additive .

quillback.explanation: A North American freshwater fish (Carpiodes cyprinus) that has one ray of the dorsal fin extending conspicuously beyond the others.
The sailfish, spear-fish, or skimback, Carpiodes cyprinus , a kind of carp-sucker. The name is also given to other fishes of that genus, as C. difformis.
An American fresh-water fish ( Ictiobus cyprinus syn. Carpiodes cyprinus ); -- called also carp sucker , sailfish , spearfish , and skimback .
Carpiodes cyprinus, a freshwater fish of the sucker family with a long filament that extends back from the dorsal fin .

quilled.explanation: quilled calisaya, contrasted with flat calisaya.
heraldry , having a quill: said of a feather employed as a bearing, and used only when the quill of a feather is of a different tincture from the rest.
Furnished with quills; also, shaped like quills.

a variety of stitch in which the threads after being passed deeply through the edges of a wound are secured about two quills or bodies of similar shape, in order to produce a suitable degree of pressure.
having long , narrow petals or florets
created through the process of quilling
Simple past tense and past participle of quill .

quiller.explanation: One who creates decorative designs from thin strips of curled paper .

quillet.explanation: A nicety or subtlety; a quibble.
A croft, or small separate piece of ground.
A small plot of land ; historically: a strip of land that together with others like it formed a larger field.

quilling.explanation: The art or craft of making decorative designs out of thin strips of rolled paper.
A narrow bordering of net, lace, or ribbon plaited so as to resemble a row of quills.
A band of linen, muslin, or the like, fluted, folded, or plaited so as somewhat to resemble a row of quills.
One of the rounded plaits or flutings of such a band.
the art of creating decorative designs from thin strips of curled paper
a band of fluted muslin resembling a row of quills

quillon.explanation: One of the arms or branches of the cross-guard of a sword. See cross-guard, cross-hilt , cut in next column, and cut under hilt .
The guard of a sword or other bladed weapon designed to protect the hand from harm .

quilltail.explanation: The ruddy duck, Erismatura rubida , Also called quilltail coot .

quillwork.explanation: Material or ornamentation made with overlaid porcupine quills by certain Native Americans.
decorative textile embellishment made from porcupine quills by certain Native Americans

quillwort.explanation: Any of several vascular, spore-bearing, aquatic or marsh plants of the genus Isoetes, having quill-like leaves.
A plant, Isoëtcs lacustris : so called from the quill-like leaves; also, any plant of the genus Isoëles. See lsoëtes and Merlin's-grass.

Any plant or species of the genus Isoetes, cryptogamous plants with a cluster of elongated four-tubed rushlike leaves, rising from a corm, and containing spores in their enlarged and excavated bases. There are about seventeen American species, usually growing in the mud under still, shallow water. So called from the shape of the shape of the leaves.
Any of various simple microphyllous vascular plants , of the family Isoetaceae, that resemble rushes and produce spores .
any of several spore-bearing aquatic or marsh plants having short rhizomes and leaves resembling quills; worldwide except Polynesia

quilt.explanation: A coverlet or blanket made of two layers of fabric with a layer of cotton, wool, feathers, or down in between, all stitched firmly together, usually in a decorative design.
A thick protective cover similar to or suggestive of a quilt.
To make into a quilt by stitching (layers of fabric) together.
To construct like a quilt.
To pad and stitch ornamentally.
To make a quilt.
To do quilted work.
A mattress or flock-bed.
A cover or coverlet made by stitching together two thicknesses of a fabric with some soft substance between them; any thick or warm coverlet: as, a patchwork quilt.
A quilted petticoat.
In building , a coarse, rough fabric used as a wall-lining in wooden houses.

quilt a petticoat; in general, to stitch together: said of anything of which there are at least three layers or thicknesses, the stitching often taking an ornamental character, the lines crossing one another or arranged in curves, volutes, etc.
The point in the throat where swallowing begins.

Anything that is quilted; esp., a quilted bed cover, or a skirt worn by women; any cover or garment made by putting wool, cotton, etc., between two cloths and stitching them together; also, any outer bed cover.
To stitch or sew together at frequent intervals, in order to confine in place the several layers of cloth and wadding of which a garment, comforter, etc., may be made.
To wad, as a garment, with warm soft material.
To stitch or sew in lines or patterns.
A bed covering consisting of two layers of fabric stitched together, with insulation between, often having a decorative design .
To construct a quilt.
To construct something, such as clothing , using the same technique.
stitch or sew together
create by stitching together
bedding made of two layers of cloth filled with stuffing and stitched together

quilted.explanation: Having the characteristics of a quilt ; specifically, having two layers of cloth sewn together, with a layer of padding between them.
Having characteristics that approximate the above to some degree, eg, quilted toilet paper .
Simple past tense and past participle of quilt .
made of layers of fabric held together by patterned stitching

quilter.explanation: One who quilts; one who makes quilting.
An attachment to sewing-machines for executing quilting upon fabrics.
One who, or that which, quilts.
A person whose hobby or profession is making quilts .
A person who uses a hand or machine stitch to decorate a quilt , or to sew together the layers of a quilt.
A person who performs the entire process of making a patchwork quilt, whether or not it is decorated with quilting stitches.

quilting.explanation: The process of doing quilted work.
Nautical : A beating with a rope's end.
A coating for a water-vessel (such as an earthen monkey or jar), formed of sennit, rope-strands, etc.
The act or operation of forming a quilt.
The material used for making quilts; padding or lining.

A kind of cloth resembling diaper, having a pattern slightly marked by the direction of the threads or raised in low relief. It is made of cotton and of linen, and is used, like piqué, for waistcoats.
The act of stitching or running in patterns, as in making a quilt.
The material used for making quilts.
A coating of strands of rope for a water vessel.
A layer or layers of quilted padding .
A coating of strands of rope for a water vessel.
a material used for making a quilt, or a quilted fabric
stitching through layers of fabric and a filling so as to create a design

quilts.explanation: Third person singular simple present of to quilt .

quin.explanation: A kind of scallop or pecten. Also queen, squin.
A European scallop ( Pecten opercularis ), used as food.
A European scallop , Pecten opercularis, used as food .
one of five children born at the same time from the same pregnancy

quina.explanation: The bark of various species of Cinchona : also applied in Brazil to some other febrifugal barks.

quinacrine.explanation: A drug with various applications, including as an antimalarial , having the chemical formula C23H30ClN3O
a drug (trade name Atabrine) used to treat certain worm infestations and once used to treat malaria

quinaldine.explanation: A base, α -methylquinoline, used in the preparation of certain artificial dyestuffs. Also chinaldine .

A colorless liquid of a slightly pungent odor, C9H6N.CH3, first obtained as a condensation product of aldehyde and aniline, and regarded as a derivative of quinoline; -- called also methyl quinoline .
An oily liquid, α- methyl quinoline , derived from coal tar , used in the manufacture of pharmaceuticals and as a sedative for fish .

quinaldinic.explanation: Of or pertaining to quinaldinic acid or its derivatives

quinamicine.explanation: An artificial alkaloid obtained from quinamine. Its formula is C 19 H 24 N 2 O 2 .

quinamidine.explanation: An artificial alkaloid obtained from quinamine. It is isomeric with quinamicine.

quinamine.explanation: A natural crystalline alkaloid, with the formula C 19 H 24 N 2 O 2 , obtained from various cinchona barks. Also called quinamia .

quinaquina.explanation: The bark of various species of Cinchona. See kin-kina .

quinarian.explanation: In zoology , one who proposed, practised, or taught the quinary system of classification; an adherent of the quinary system.
Describing a system of classification based on the quinary system
An advocate of this method of classification

quinarius.explanation: An ancient Roman republican and imperial silver coin, in value half the denarius, or about 8 cents United States money.
A small silver coin minted during the Roman Republic , equal to half of a denarius .

quinary.explanation: A whole composed of five parts or elements.
Consisting of five; arranged by fives.
a fanciful classification based on the hypothesis that each group contains five types.
Consisting of five things; arranged in fives
To the base of five; represented by the numerals 0, 1, 2, 3 and 4.

quinate.explanation: botany , having an arrangement of five similar parts together, as five leaflets on a petiole.
In chem. , a salt of quinic acid.
Growing in sets of five; -- said especially of leaves composed of five leaflets set at the end of a common petiole.
An ester or a salt of quinic acid .
Featuring five leaflets growing from a single point; quinquefoliolate .

quinazoline.explanation: The name given to phenmiazin, , and to its derivatives. It crystallizes in leaflets which melt at 48° and it boils at 243° C.
A bicyclic aromatic heterocycle consisting of a benzene ring fused to one of pyrimidine ; some of its derivatives are pharmaceuticals

quince.explanation: A shrub or small tree (Cydonia oblonga) in the rose family, native to western Asia, having white or pink flowers and hard yellow pear-shaped fruit.
The aromatic, many-seeded fruit of this plant, usually used for jelly or in cooked dishes.
The fruit of the tree Pyrus Cydonia. (See def. 2.)
The fruit-tree Pyrus Cydonia , sometimes classed as Cydonia vulgaris , the latter genus being based (insufficiently) on the many-seeded cells of the fruit.

The fruit of a shrub ( Cydonia vulgaris ) belonging to the same tribe as the apple. It somewhat resembles an apple, but differs in having many seeds in each carpel. It has hard flesh of high flavor, but very acid, and is largely used for marmalade, jelly, and preserves.

an Eastern Asiatic shrub ( Cydonia Japonica , formerly Pyrus Japonica ) and its very fragrant but inedible fruit. The shrub has very showy flowers, usually red, but sometimes pink or white, and is much grown for ornament.
a small gray and yellow curculio ( Conotrachelus cratægi ) whose larva lives in quinces.
the small tree ( Cydonia vulgaris ) which produces the quince.
The pear-shaped fruit of a small tree of the rose family, Cydonia oblonga .
The deciduous tree bearing such fruit, native to Asia .
aromatic acid-tasting pear-shaped fruit used in preserves
small Asian tree with pinkish flowers and pear-shaped fruit; widely cultivated

quincentenary.explanation: Of or relating to a span of 500 years or to a 500th anniversary.
That which consists of or comprehends five hundred.
the 500th anniversary (or the celebration of it)
of or relating to a 500th anniversary

quincentennial.explanation: the 500th anniversary (or the celebration of it)
of or relating to a 500th anniversary

quincubital.explanation: ornithology , possessing a fifth cubital remex or secondary quill.

quincuncial.explanation: Of, relating to, or forming a quincunx.
botany , sometimes noting a pentastichous arrangement of leaves; more often noting an estivation.

quincuncially.explanation: In the manner or order of a quincunx.

quincunx.explanation: An arrangement of five objects or marks with one at each corner of a rectangle or square and one at the center.
A Roman brass coin of five unciæ.
A reliquary in the shape of a cross, the four parts of which can be folded over the central one.
An arrangement of five objects in a square, one at each corner and one in the middle (thus, ); especially, an arrangement, as of trees, in such squares continuously.
In botany , same as quincuncial estivation (which see, under quincuncial ).
In astrology , the position of planets when distant from each other five signs or 150°.

An arrangement of things by fives in a square or a rectangle, one being placed at each corner and one in the middle; especially, such an arrangement of trees repeated indefinitely, so as to form a regular group with rows running in various directions.
The position of planets when distant from each other five signs, or 150°.
A quincuncial arrangement, as of the parts of a flower in æstivation. See Quincuncial , 2.
An arrangement of five units in a pattern corresponding to the five-spot on dice , playing cards, or dominoes .
An angle of five-twelfths of a circle, or 150°, between two objects.
A bronze coin minted during the Roman Republic , valued at five-twelfths of an as .

quindecad.explanation: A set or series of fifteen.

quindecagon.explanation: In geometry , a plane figure with fifteen sides and fifteen angles.
A plane figure with fifteen angles, and consequently fifteen sides.

quindecemvir.explanation: In Roman antiquity , one of a body of fifteen magistrates who, at the close of the republic, had charge of the Sibylline books.
One of a sacerdotal college of fifteen men whose chief duty was to take care of the Sibylline books.

quindecemvirate.explanation: The body or office of the quindecemvirs.
The body or office of the quindecemviri.

quindecima.explanation: In music , the interval of a fifteenth, or double octave.
An organ-stop two octaves above the foundation-stops.

quindecylic.explanation: Pertaining to, or designating, an acid of the fatty acid series, containing fifteen atoms of carbon; called also pentadecylic acid.

quindene.explanation: The fifteenth day, counting inclusively from a certain date.

quinella.explanation: A system of betting in which the bettor, in order to win, must pick the first two finishers of a race, but not necessarily in the correct sequence.
A form of bet in which the bettor predicts the first two finishers in a race, without concern for the order of finishing.
To have two team members, horses, etc., finish first and second in the same event.

quinetum.explanation: A trade-name of a mixture of the alkaloids from Cinchona succirubra , used medicinally in the treatment of intermittent fever in malarial districts. Also chinetum .

quinhydrone.explanation: A dark-green crystalline compound, C 6 H. 4 O 2 .C 6 H 4 (OH) 2 , made by mixing solutions of quinone and hydroquinone, by the partial reduction of quinone, or by partly oxidizing hydroquinone by means of ferric chlorid. It breaks down into quinone and hydroquinone when boiled with water, and melts at 171° C.
A green crystalline substance formed by the union of quinone with hydroquinone, or as an intermediate product in the oxidation of hydroquinone or the reduction of quinone.
a molecular complex of a quinone and its corresponding hydroquinone

quinible.explanation: In music , an interval of a fifth; a descant sung at the fifth.
music , to sing a descant at the interval of a fifth. See diaphony , 2.
An interval of a fifth; also, a part sung with such intervals.
An interval of a fifth , or a part sung with such intervals.

quinic.explanation: Pertaining to, derived from, or connected with, quinine and related compounds; specifically, designating a nonnitrogenous acid obtained from cinchona bark, coffee, beans, etc., as a white crystalline substance.
Of, pertaining to, or derived from quinine

quinicine.explanation: The isomeric alkaloid into which quinine or quinidine is converted by heat, differing from them in being dextrogyrate and amorphous.
An uncrystallizable alkaloid obtained by the action of heat from quinine, with which it is isomeric.
An uncrystallizable alkaloid obtained by the action of heat from quinine , with which it is isomeric .

quinidine.explanation: A colorless crystalline alkaloid, C 20 H 24 N 2 O 2 , resembling quinine and used in treating malaria and cardiac arrhythmias.
A base (C 20 H 24 N 2 O 2 ) isomeric with quinine, and occurring associated with it in some cinchona barks.

An alkaloid isomeric with, and resembling, quinine, found in certain species of cinchona, from which it is extracted as a bitter white crystalline substance; conchinine. It is used somewhat as a febrifuge.
An isomer of quinine that is used as an antiarrhythmic agent
cardiac drug (trade names Quinidex and Quinora) used to treat certain heart arrhythmias

quinine.explanation: A bitter, colorless, amorphous powder or crystalline alkaloid, C 20 H 24 N 2 O 2 · 3H 2 O, derived from certain cinchona barks and used in medicine to treat malaria.
Any of various compounds or salts of quinine.
A very important vegetable alkali (C 20 H 24 N 2 O 2 ), obtained from the bark of several trees of the genus Cinchona.

An alkaloid extracted from the bark of several species of cinchona (esp. Cinchona Calisaya ) as a bitter white crystalline substance, C20H24N2O2. Hence, by extension (Med.), any of the salts of this alkaloid, as the acetate, chloride, sulphate, etc., employed as a febrifuge or antiperiodic. Called also quinia , quinina , etc.
A bitter colourless powder , an alkaloid derived from cinchona bark , used to treat malaria and as an ingredient of tonic water .
a bitter alkaloid extracted from chinchona bark; used in malaria therapy

quininic.explanation: Pertaining to, or designating, a nitrogenous acid obtained as a yellow crystalline substance by the oxidation of quinine.

quiniretin.explanation: The flocculent precipitate deposited in solutions of quinine by the action of sunlight. It has the same chemical composition as quinine, but no alkaloidal properties.

quinisextine.explanation: a. d. , the complement of the fifth and sixth ecumenical councils held at Constantinople. See Constantinopolitan Council , under Constantinopolitan.

quinite.explanation: A bitter-sweet substance, C 6 H 10 (OH) or 1,4-dihydroxyhexahydrobenzene, made by the action of sodium amalgam and carbon dioxid on diketohexamethylene. It melts at 144° C. Also called quinitol .

quinizarin.explanation: A red, or yellowish-red, crystalline substance, C 6 H 4 (CO) 2 C 6 H 2 (OH) 2 or 1,4-dihydroxyanthraquinone, made by heating together phthalic anhydrid and hydroquinone; also in other ways. It gives blue solutions with alkalis. It melts at 192–193° C.
A yellow crystalline substance produced artificially and isomeric with alizarin .

quinnat.explanation: The king-salmon, Oncorhynchus quinnat. Also called chavicha and equinna. See Oncorhynchus and salmon.
The California salmon ( Oncorhynchus choicha ); -- called also chouicha , king salmon , chinook salmon , and Sacramento salmon . It is of great commercial importance.

quinoa.explanation: A goosefoot (Chenopodium quinoa) native to the Andes and cultivated for its edible seeds.
The seeds of this plant, used as food.
An annual herb, Chenopodium Quinoa , native in Peru, Chili, etc., and there much cultivated for its farinaceous seeds.
The seeds of a kind of goosewort ( Chenopodium Quinoa ), used in Chili and Peru for making porridge or cakes; also, food thus made.
A goosefoot , Chenopodium quinoa, native to the Andes and cultivated for its edible seeds.
The high- protein dried fruits and seeds of this plant, used as a food staple and ground into flour .

quinoform.explanation: A dry, bulky powder formed by precipitating an aqueous extract of cinchona to which formaldehyde has been added with hydrochloric acid: used as a dusting-powder in dermatology. Also chinoform .

quinogen.explanation: An intermediate product, dimethylquinogen, , formed in the synthesis of p-xyloquinone from diacetyl; also, a similar product obtained in the synthesis of duroquinone.
A hypothetical radical of quinine and related alkaloids.
A hypothetical radical of quinine and related alkaloids .

quinoid.explanation: Having a structure based upon a quinone
Any substance whose structure is based upon a quinone .

quinoidine.explanation: A brownish resinous substance obtained as a by-product in the treatment of cinchona bark. It consists of a mixture of several alkaloids.
A brownish resinous substance obtained as a by-product in the treatment of cinchona bark .

quinol.explanation: A partial reduction of a quinone , a diene of the cyclohexadienediones class of biochemicals.

quinoline.explanation: An aromatic organic base, C 9 H 7 N, having a pungent tarlike odor, synthesized or obtained from coal tar, and used as a food preservative and in making antiseptics, drugs, and dyes.

A nitrogenous base, C9H7N obtained as a pungent colorless liquid by the distillation of alkaloids, bones, coal tar, etc. It the nucleus of many organic bodies, especially of certain alkaloids and related substances; hence, by extension, any one of the series of alkaloidal bases of which quinoline proper is the type.
Any of a class of aromatic heterocyclic compounds containing a benzene ring fused with a pyridine ring; especially the simplest such compound, C9H7N.

quinolinic.explanation: Of or pertaining to quinolinic acid or its derivatives

quinolinium.explanation: The cation formed by protonation of a quinoline

quinologist.explanation: One who is versed in quinology.
One who is versed in quinology.

quinology.explanation: The sum of scientific knowledge concerning quinine and other cinchona alkaloids.
The science which treats of the cultivation of the cinchona, and of its use in medicine.
The science of the cultivation of cinchona and its use in medicine as quinine .

quinolyl.explanation: A univalent radical derived from quinoline

quinone.explanation: Either of two isomeric unsaturated cyclic compounds having the formula C 6 H 4 O 2 , found widely in plants, especially in a yellow crystalline form, and used in making dyes, tanning hides, and photography.
Any of various quinonoid compounds, often yellow to red in color, many of which have biological derivation or importance, such as coenzyme-Q.
The general name applied to all benzene derivatives in which two hydrogen atoms are replaced by two oxygen atoms.
Specifically, a compound obtained by distilling kinic acid with diluted sulphuric acid and peroxid of manganese, or by the oxidation of aniline with chromic acid.

A crystalline substance, C6H4O2 (called also benzoketone ), first obtained by the oxidation of quinic acid and regarded as a double ketone; also, by extension, any one of the series of which quinone proper is the type.
any of a class of aromatic compounds having two carbonyl functional groups in the same six-membered ring
any of a class of aromatic yellow compounds including several that are biologically important as coenzymes or acceptors or vitamins; used in making dyes

quinonimine.explanation: Any of a class of imines formally derived from a quinone by replacing one or both oxygens with =NR.

quinonoid.explanation: Of or containing quinone or resembling it in structure or properties; quinoid.
of, relating to, or having the structure of a quinone

quinopyrin.explanation: A trade-name of a solution of quinine hydrochlorate and antipyrin, for medicinal use as a febrifuge.

quinotoxine.explanation: A derivative of quinine that has a historical importance in the synthesis of the drug

quinovic.explanation: Pertaining to, or designating, a crystalline acid obtained from some varieties of cinchona bark.
Of or pertaining to quinovic acid

quinovin.explanation: An amorphous bitter glucoside derived from cinchona and other barks. Called also quinova bitter , and quinova .
An amorphous bitter glucoside derived from cinchona and other barks .

quinovose.explanation: A deoxy sugar , 6-deoxy-D-glucopyranose, that is widespread in plants, often as a sulfate

quinoxalin.explanation: A synthetic crystalline base, . It may be regarded as quinoline with the CH group in the para position to nitrogen replaced by a second atom of nitrogen.

quinoxaline.explanation: Any one of a series of complex nitrogenous bases obtained by the union of certain aniline derivatives with glyoxal or with certain ketones.
A bicyclic heterocycle consisting of a benzene ring fused to that of pyrazine .

quinoyl.explanation: A radical of which quinone is the hydride, analogous to phenyl.
A radical whose hydride is quinone , analogous to phenyl .

quinquagenarian.explanation: A person 50 years old, or in his or her fifties.
Of or characteristic of a person in his or her fifties.
A person aged fifty or between fifty and sixty.
One who is between the age of 50 and 59, inclusive.
Being between the age of 50 and 59, inclusive.
Of or relating to a quinquagenarian.

quinquarticular.explanation: Relating to the five articles or points.
Relating to the five articles of Remonstrance.

quinquecapsular.explanation: botany and zoology , having five capsules.

quinquecostate.explanation: zoology and botany , having five ribs or costæ, in any sense.

quinquedentate.explanation: botany and zoology , having five teeth or serrations of any kind.
Having a pattern of five teeth .

quinquedentated.explanation: Having a pattern of five teeth .

quinquefarious.explanation: botany , disposed in five vertical ranks.
zoology , disposed or arranged in five sets, rows, or series; quinqueserial; pentastichous.
Arranged in five vertical rows; pentastichous.

quinquefid.explanation: botany , cleft into five segments. See cleft , 2.
Sharply cut about halfway to the middle or base into five segments.
Sharply cut about halfway to the middle or base into five segments .

quinquefoliate.explanation: botany , having five leaves, or, more commonly but less properly, five leaflets.
(of a leaf shape) having five leaflets

quinquefoliolate.explanation: botany , having five leaflets: said of compound leaves.

quinquelobate.explanation: botany and zoology , having five lobes.
Cut less than halfway into portions, usually somewhat rounded; five-lobed.

quinquelocular.explanation: zoology and botany , having five loculi, cavities, or cells.
Having five cells or loculi; five-celled.

quinquenerved.explanation: Having five nerves; -- said of a leaf with five nearly equal nerves or ribs rising from the end of the petiole.
Having five nerves ; said of a leaf with five nearly equal nerves or ribs rising from the end of the petiole .

quinquennalia.explanation: Roman antiquity , public games celebrated every fifth year. See quinquennial , n., 2.
Public games celebrated every five years.
Public games celebrated every five years in Ancient Rome .

quinquennial.explanation: A period of five years; a quinquenniad; hence, something characterized by such a period or interval, as an anniversary, or a college catalogue.
A festival or celebration occurring once in four years; an anniversary in the fifth year.
Occurring once in five years, or at the end of every five years; also, lasting five years. A quinquennial event.

quinquepartite.explanation: Divided into five parts almost to the base.

quinquepetaloid.explanation: quinquepetaloid rosette of a spatangoid sea-urchin.

quinquereme.explanation: An ancient galley having five banks of oars.
